data.title: Trail Blazers trade Andre Miller to Denver for Raymond Felton; Rudy Fernandez headed to Dallas
data.meta_description: Blazers also draft Duke point guard Nolan Smith at No. 21, giving the team a new starter and a new backup at point guard and Rudy Fernandez and the rights to Petteri Koponen are sent to Dallas as part of the three-team deal.
data.text:
The Trail Blazers have addressed their needs at point guard.

The Blazers on Thursday got both experience and youth at point guard, trading Andre Miller to Denver for veteran point guard

and drafting Duke point guard

with the No. 21 overall pick.

Andy Miller, the agent for Andre Miller, confirmed the trade.

Blazers interim general manager Chad Buchanan did not return messages and scout Mike Born said he would not comment.

Dallas is also reported to be in the deal, acquiring Rudy Fernandez and the rights to Petteri Koponen from the Blazers in exchange for their first-round pick (No. 26 overall). Portland will send that pick to Denver.

Smith, a four-year player at Duke, was the ACC Player of the Year, averaging 20.6 points.

Thursday accomplishes the Blazers' desire to become both younger at point guard while not sacrificing experience.

Felton, who turns 27 on Sunday, has played six NBA seasons, and is coming off one of his best years playing for both the New York Knicks and the Denver Nuggets. Felton (6-foot-1, 205 pounds) is regarded as a strong pick-and-roll player with below-average outside shooting.

Miller, 35, played two stellar seasons for the Blazers and will head back to Denver, where he played three and a half seasons.

Denver will now assume Miller's contract, which has a team option for $7.8 million that must be picked up before June 30. Felton has one year remaining on his contract, which will pay him $7.56 million.

Felton last season posted career highs in points (15.5) and assists (8.3). He signed a two-year free agent deal before the season with New York, but was included in the Carmelo Anthony blockbuster trade with Denver.

The fifth overall pick by Charlotte in the 2005 draft, directly behind Deron Williams and Chris Paul, Felton was an All-Rookie second-team selection. He played five seasons in Charlotte, where he is the Bobcats career-leader in assists (2,573). Felton won a National Championship at North Carolina in his junior season, then declared early for the NBA Draft.

Like Miller, Felton has been a durable player, in every season having played in at least 75 of the 82 regular-season games. He also had a career-high 126 steals in 2008-2009.

If there are two weaknesses to Felton, it is his size – the Blazers posted him relentlessly in a November matchup in New York – and his shooting. He is a career 41.2 percent shooter (Miller was 45.9 percent career shooter), which includes a career mark of 33.3 percent from three-point range. He does, however, pose at least a threat from the outside, making a career-high 116 three's last season, which will help the Blazers' spacing.

One of the complications with Miller on the Blazers was his poor outside shot, which allowed teams to play off him and clog the middle. Miller made only four three pointers in 37 attempts last season and is a career 20.4 percent three-point shooter.

Smith (6-foot-3, 185 pounds) was a consensus first-team All-American his senior year and helped the Blue Devils win the NCAA Championship his junior season.

"We've seen him for so long,'' Buchanan said this month after Smith worked out at the Blazers' facility in Tualatin. "He's just a rock-solid, high-character guy. He's improved at the college level, and he's improved every year, which we like. (He) can score it. Good defender - that was kind of his identity coming into college. He evolved into a pretty good offensive player as well.''

Smith averaged 5.9 points as a freshman, 8.4 points as a sophomore, and 17.4 points as a junior before a stellar senior season when he averaged 20.6 points, 4.5 rebounds, 5.1 assists and 1.2 steals.

"When we grade him out statistically, he grades out very high for us,'' Buchanan said. "We had dinner with Nolan in Chicago and we think highly of him as a person, too.''
